title: Using Scrapy for Movie Recommendations
text:
In this tutorial, I will be creating a web crawler with scrapy, which I will use to scrape TMDB in order to make a primitive movie recommendation system by counting the number of shared actors with various films/TV shows. (The repo for this project can be found here)

Setup
Start by opening a terminal and typing the following commands (assuming you already have conda installed with scrapy):
conda activate Environment_Name
scrapy startproject TMDB_scraper
cd TMDB_scraper
This will create a folder called TMDB_scraper in your current directory. Navigate to /TMND_scraper/TMND_scraper/settings.py and set the USER_AGENT variable to a user agent of your choosing. This will help bypass potential Error 403s later.


Writing the scraper
Create a file in the /TMND_scraper/TMND_scraper/spiders directory called tmdb_spider.py. This is where the most of scraper behavior will be held.
Then, add the following code block to the beginning of the file:
import scrapy

class TmdbSpider(scrapy.Spider):
    name = 'tmdb_spider'
    def __init__(self, subdir=None, *args, **kwargs):
        self.start_urls = [f"https://www.themoviedb.org/movie/{subdir}/"]
This defines the basic structure of the scraper. Next, add the following three methods to the file:
def parse(self, response):
    """
    Parses TMDB movie pages.
    Yields a scrapy.Request for the "Full Cast & Crew" page, with the parse_full_credit method specified in the callback argument.
    Does not return any data.
    """
    yield scrapy.Request(response.url+"/cast/", callback = self.parse_full_credits)
As the docstring states, this method takes a TMDB movie page and navigates to the “Full Cast & Crew” page by just appending “/cast/” to the url.
This page is then passed into the parse_full_credits method, defined below:
def parse_full_credits(self, response):
    """
    Parses TMDB "Full Cast & Crew" pages.
    Yields a scrapy.Request for the page of each cast member, with the parse_actor_page method specified in the callback argument.
    Does not return any data.
    """
    #Select only the Cast section
    cast = response.css("ol.people.credits")[0]
    #Select actor names
    for href in cast.css("p a::attr(href)").getall():
        yield scrapy.Request(response.urljoin(href), callback = self.parse_actor_page)
This method takes the “Full Cast & Crew” page and navigates to the cast members’ pages. It does this by selecting a css element containing the details of the cast members, then selecting all of the links in that section. Note the [0] index on the cast object! Leaving this off would select crew members as well, which is not what we want.
The pages from this method are passed into the parse_actor_pages method, defined below:
def parse_actor_page(self, response):
    """
    Parses TMDB actor pages.
    Yields a dictionary containing the actor's name keyed by "actor" and the movie/TV show keyed by "movie_or_TV_name" for each movie/TV show they have acted in.
    """
    #Select actor name
    actor = response.css("h2.title a::text").get()

    #Figure out which section is the "Acting" section by examining all the headers
    acting_index = response.css("div.credits_list h3::text").getall().index("Acting")
    #Select all acting roles
    acting = response.css("div.credits_list table.card.credits")[acting_index]
    for title in acting.css("a.tooltip bdi::text"):
        yield {"actor": actor, "movie_or_TV_name": title.get()}
First, this method finds the actor’s name on the page. This is easily accomplished by looking for the h2 css tag and taking the text under it.
However, finding the sections with their acting roles is a little trickier. We first select all of the h3 headers under div.credits_list, looking for the one that says “Acting”. Then, we store the index and use it to select the corresponding table under div.credits_list. From there, we can easily select all of the titles. For the output, we yield a dictionary consisting of the actor’s name and the movie/TV series name for each acting credit.


Running the scraper
Once all of this is done, running the scraper is a relatively simple task. Simply type into the terminal:
scrapy crawl tmdb_spider -o results.csv -a subdir=9323-ghost-in-the-shell
Of course, you can replace the subdir argument with whatever movie you like. This command will produce a csv file in /TMDB_scraper/results.csv containing all of the actor/movie information for the given movie.


Reading the data
We can just use pandas to read the results from the results.csv file.

import pandas as pd
df = pd.read_csv("TMDB_scraper/results.csv")

We can use pandas’s .value_counts() method to count the number of times each movie appears in the dataframe. This returns a series, so we need to do some manipulation to get it into a dataframe. We also rename the columns to make them look more professional for plotting.

counts = df["movie_or_TV_name"].value_counts()
counts = counts.to_frame()
counts = counts.reset_index()
counts.rename(columns={"movie_or_TV_name": "Movie or TV show name","count": "Number of shared actors"},inplace=True)

Plotting the data
We use plotly with the data, making a bar chart of the top 10 movies/TV shows sharing actors with Ghost in the Shell in this case.

import plotly.io as pio
pio.renderers.default="iframe" #For rendering on the blog
from plotly import express as px

fig = px.bar(counts.head(10),
                x="Movie or TV show name",
                y="Number of shared actors",
                title = "Top 10 Movies/TV Shows with most actors in common with Ghost in the Shell")
fig.show()




Unsurprisingly, Ghost in the Shell has the most actors in common with Ghost in the Shell. It’s also unsurprising that the various spin-offs of Ghost in the Shell also share a few actors. Cowboy Bebop, Monster, and Black Jack are all anime that ran during the same era, so it makes sense that they would share actors.

text:
In this blog post, I will be describing how to make a simple line plot of the Palmer Penguins dataset.

Importing packages and getting data
To start, we first import pandas in order to download and read the dataset.

import pandas as pd
url = "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/pic16b-ucla/24W/main/datasets/palmer_penguins.csv"
penguins = pd.read_csv(url)

To help with plotting, we import matplotlib and seaborn (a library for matplotlib).

import seaborn as sns 
from matplotlib import pyplot as plt
import numpy as np



Selecting Data
We select only the subset of data that pertains to Adelie penguins.

adelie = penguins[penguins["Species"] == "Adelie Penguin (Pygoscelis adeliae)"]



Plotting Data
Finally, we can plot the data using seaborn’s lineplot function by specifying the dataset and the axes we wish to plot against.

sns.lineplot(data = adelie, x = "Flipper Length (mm)", y = "Body Mass (g)").set(title="Flipper Length (mm) vs Body Mass (g) for Adelie Penguins")

title: Analysis of Temperature Data for Countries
text:
#Included to make the plots interactive
import plotly.io as pio
pio.renderers.default="iframe"


Setting Up the Database
Most of this code is taken from the lecture “Working with Datasets”:
We first clean up the dataframes, then add them as databases using sqlite3.

with open("database_setup.py", 'r') as f:
    print(f.read())

import sqlite3
import pandas as pd

#Mostly taken from the lecture "Working with Datasets"
def prepare_df(df):
    df = df.set_index(keys=["ID", "Year"])
    df = df.stack()
    df = df.reset_index()
    df = df.rename(columns = {"level_2"  : "Month" , 0 : "Temp"})
    df["Month"] = df["Month"].str[5:].astype(int)
    df["Temp"]  = df["Temp"] / 100
    return(df)

with sqlite3.connect("temps.db") as conn: # create a database in current directory called temps.db
    temps_iter = pd.read_csv("temps.csv", chunksize = 100000)
    for i, df in enumerate(temps_iter):
        df = prepare_df(df)
        df.to_sql("temperatures", conn, if_exists = "replace" if i == 0 else "append", index = False)
    url = "station-metadata.csv"
    stations = pd.read_csv(url)
    stations.to_sql("stations", conn, if_exists = "replace", index=False)
    countries = pd.read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/mysociety/gaze/master/data/fips-10-4-to-iso-country-codes.csv")
    countries.to_sql("countries", conn, if_exists = "replace", index=False)




Querying the Database
The vast majority of the query_climate_database function is a single SQL query. We select the relevant columns and only take rows satisfying the given constraints. Since country and station data is not in the temperatures database, we need to do some merges in order to get all the relevant information into one table.

import inspect
from climate_database import query_climate_database
print(inspect.getsource(query_climate_database))

def query_climate_database(db_file, country, year_begin, year_end, month):
    """
    Query a climate database for temperature information

    Args:
        db_file: sqlite3 database file
        country (str): Country to take temperature data
        year_begin (int): Year to begin taking data
        year_end (int): Year to stop taking data
        month (int): Month to take temperature data
    
    Returns:
        df: Dataframe of temperature data at the provided country in the provided time range
    """

    cmd = \
    f"""
    SELECT S.name, S.latitude, S.longitude, C.Name, T.year, T.month, T.temp 
    FROM temperatures T
    LEFT JOIN stations S ON T.id = S.id
    INNER JOIN countries C ON SUBSTR(S.id,1,2) = C."FIPS 10-4"
    WHERE C.Name = "{country}" AND T.month = {month} AND T.year >= {year_begin} AND T.year <= {year_end}
    """
    with sqlite3.connect(db_file) as conn:
        df = pd.read_sql_query(cmd, conn)
        df.rename(columns={"Name": "Country"},inplace=True)
    return df

Plotting the Data
In order to first filter out stations that do not have enough observation data, we add a column showing the number of years each sation has been providing data for using transform, which we can then use to filter out those rows.
With transform, we can estimate the yearly temperature increase using linear regression. Finally, we use plotly’s scatter_mapbox function to make a plot of the data.

import plotly
from plotly import express as px
import numpy as np
import calendar
from sklearn.linear_model import LinearRegression

def temperature_coefficient_plot(db_file, country, year_begin, year_end, month, min_obs, **kwargs):
    """
    Use a climate database to make a geographic scatterplot

    Args:
        db_file: sqlite3 database file
        country (str): Country to take temperature data
        year_begin (int): Year to begin taking data
        year_end (int): Year to stop taking data
        month (int): Month to take temperature data
        min_obs (int): Minimum number of years with recordings for stations
        **kwargs: Additional arguments to be passed into scatter_mapbox 
    Returns:
        fig: Geographic scatterplot of data
    """

    #collect data
    df = query_climate_database(db_file, country, year_begin, year_end, month)
    
    # we don't need the month and country columns anymore since month and country are arguments of the function
    df = df.drop(["Month","Country"], axis=1)

    # filter out stations with range of years of operation less than min_obs
    df["obs"] = df.groupby(["NAME", "LATITUDE", "LONGITUDE"])["Year"].transform(np.ptp)
    df = df[df["obs"]>min_obs]

    # defined in the lecture "Advanced Data Manipulation II": uses linear regression to calculate the estimated yearly increase
    def coef(data_group):
        x = data_group[["Year"]] # 2 brackets because X should be a df
        y = data_group["Temp"]   # 1 bracket because y should be a series
        LR = LinearRegression()
        LR.fit(x, y)
        return LR.coef_[0]

    # add a column for the yearly increase
    df = df.groupby(["NAME", "LATITUDE", "LONGITUDE"]).apply(coef)
    df = df.reset_index()
    df[0] = df[0].round(4)
    df.rename(columns={0: "Estimated Yearly Increase (°C)"},inplace=True)

    # create the plot with all the gathered information
    fig = px.scatter_mapbox(df, 
                            title = f"Estimates of yearly increase in temperature in {calendar.month_name[month]}<br>for stations in {country}, years {year_begin} - {year_end}",
                            hover_name = "NAME",
                            lat = "LATITUDE",
                            lon = "LONGITUDE", 
                            color = "Estimated Yearly Increase (°C)",
                            **kwargs)
    fig.update_coloraxes(cmid=0)
    return fig

We can now call the functions with various arguments to see what the yearly increases in temperature are across each country.

color_map = px.colors.diverging.RdGy_r

fig1 = temperature_coefficient_plot("temps.db", "India", 1980, 2020, 1, 
                                   min_obs = 10,
                                   zoom = 2,
                                   mapbox_style="carto-positron",
                                   color_continuous_scale=color_map)

fig1.show()





fig2 = temperature_coefficient_plot("temps.db", "France", 1980, 2020, 1, 
                                   min_obs = 10,
                                   zoom = 2,
                                   mapbox_style="carto-positron",
                                   color_continuous_scale=color_map)

fig2.show()






Plotting Variation in Yearly Increase
We can see by the color scale that there can be significant variation of yearly increase within a country, but exactly how much is there? We can use the same data to make a box plot of yearly increases throughout a country, again using plotly.

import pandas as pd

def temperature_box_plot(db_file, countries, year_begin, year_end, month, min_obs):
    """
    Use a climate database to make a box plot

    Args:
        db_file: sqlite3 database file
        countries (list): Countries to take temperature data
        year_begin (int): Year to begin taking data
        year_end (int): Year to stop taking data
        month (int): Month to take temperature data
        min_obs (int): Minimum number of years with recordings for stations
    Returns:
        fig: Box plot of data
    """
    df = pd.DataFrame()
    #collect data
    for country in countries:
        df = pd.concat([df,query_climate_database(db_file, country, year_begin, year_end, month)], ignore_index = True)
    
    # we don't need the month column anymore since month is an argument of the function
    df = df.drop(["Month"], axis=1)

    # filter out stations with range of years of operation less than min_obs
    df["obs"] = df.groupby(["NAME", "LATITUDE", "LONGITUDE", "Country"])["Year"].transform(np.ptp)
    df = df[df["obs"]>min_obs]

    # defined in the lecture "Advanced Data Manipulation II": uses linear regression to calculate the estimated yearly increase
    def coef(data_group):
        x = data_group[["Year"]] # 2 brackets because X should be a df
        y = data_group["Temp"]   # 1 bracket because y should be a series
        LR = LinearRegression()
        LR.fit(x, y)
        return LR.coef_[0]

    # add a column for the yearly increase
    df = df.groupby(["NAME", "LATITUDE", "LONGITUDE", "Country"]).apply(coef)
    df = df.reset_index()
    df[0] = df[0].round(4)
    df.rename(columns={0: "Estimated Yearly Increase (°C)"},inplace=True)

    # create the plot with all the gathered information
    fig = px.box(df, "Estimated Yearly Increase (°C)", facet_col="Country",
                 title=f"Variation in yearly increase in temperature in {calendar.month_name[month]}<br>for stations in {country}, years {year_begin} - {year_end}",)
    return fig


fig3 = temperature_box_plot("temps.db", ["India","China","France"], 1980, 2020, 1, min_obs = 10)
fig3.show()






Is Yearly Increase Correlated With Latitude?
We’ve seen that yearly increase can vary significantly within a country, so could this be tied to the latitude of the stations?
To answer this question, we first need another SQL querying function.
query_climate_database_long accesses the same information as query_climate_database, but it instead takes stations that are within tol degrees of a given longitude (long).

from climate_database import query_climate_database_long
import inspect
print(inspect.getsource(query_climate_database_long))

def query_climate_database_long(db_file, long, tol, year_begin, year_end, month):
    """
    Query a climate database for temperature information

    Args:
        db_file: sqlite3 database file
        long (int): Longitude to take data from
        tol (int): Tolerance for longitude value
        year_begin (int): Year to begin taking data
        year_end (int): Year to stop taking data
        month (int): Month to take temperature data
    
    Returns:
        df: Dataframe of temperature data near the provided longitude in the provided time range
    """

    cmd = \
    f"""
    SELECT S.name, S.latitude, S.longitude, T.year, T.month, T.temp 
    FROM temperatures T
    LEFT JOIN stations S ON T.id = S.id
    WHERE T.month = {month} AND T.year >= {year_begin} AND T.year <= {year_end} AND S.longitude < {long+tol} AND S.longitude > {long-tol}
    """
    with sqlite3.connect(db_file) as conn:
        df = pd.read_sql_query(cmd, conn)
    return df



We can now use this function to gather data and plot it, again using plotly.

def temperature_longitude_plot(db_file, long, tol, year_begin, year_end, month, min_obs, **kwargs):
    """
    Use a climate database to make a geographic scatterplot

    Args:
        db_file: sqlite3 database file
        long (int): Longitude to take data from
        tol (int): Tolerance for longitude value
        year_begin (int): Year to begin taking data
        year_end (int): Year to stop taking data
        month (int): Month to take temperature data
        min_obs (int): Minimum number of years with recordings for stations
        **kwargs: Additional arguments to be passed into scatter 
    Returns:
        fig: Scatterplot of data
    """
    
    #collect data
    df = query_climate_database_long(db_file, long, tol, year_begin, year_end, month)
    
    # we don't need the month column anymore since month is an argument of the function
    df = df.drop(["Month"], axis=1)

    # filter out stations with range of years of operation less than min_obs
    df["obs"] = df.groupby(["NAME", "LATITUDE", "LONGITUDE"])["Year"].transform(np.ptp)
    df = df[df["obs"]>min_obs]

    # defined in the lecture "Advanced Data Manipulation II": uses linear regression to calculate the estimated yearly increase
    def coef(data_group):
        x = data_group[["Year"]] # 2 brackets because X should be a df
        y = data_group["Temp"]   # 1 bracket because y should be a series
        LR = LinearRegression()
        LR.fit(x, y)
        return LR.coef_[0]

    # add a column for the yearly increase
    df = df.groupby(["NAME", "LATITUDE", "LONGITUDE"]).apply(coef)
    df = df.reset_index()
    df[0] = df[0].round(4)
    df.rename(columns={0: "Estimated Yearly Increase (°C)", "LATITUDE": "Latitude (°)"},inplace=True)
    
    # create the plot with all the gathered information
    fig = px.scatter(df, 
                    title = f"Estimates of yearly increase in temperature in {calendar.month_name[month]}<br>for longitudes {long-tol}° to {long+tol}°, years {year_begin} - {year_end}",
                    hover_name = "NAME",
                    x = "Latitude (°)",
                    y = "Estimated Yearly Increase (°C)",
                    **kwargs)
    return fig


fig4 = temperature_longitude_plot("temps.db", 0, 5, 1980, 2020, 1, 
                                   min_obs = 10)
fig4.show()
